data.title: Vector3 performance improvements

Batch of performance improvements for Vector3.

-Normalize

-operator !=

simplification(e.g "float" to "var")
-Negate
-Normalize
-Reflect
-ToString - removed StringBuilder
-Transform
-operator /

other:
-GetHashCode - changed to XNA behaviour
-fixed bug in Vector4.GetHashCode

+new Tests for all changed things(tested with XNA)

data.title: ContentManager.Unload(asset), More strict memory management
data.body:
I made 2 changes to the content manager when I was working on a project and came across some memory problems
#1

I noticed the absence of this crucial function, Unload(asset), in the content manager so I decided to add it. This is essentially an alternative for (resource).Dispose() when the resource is loaded through a content manager.
#2

As much as I hated to, I had to use GC.Collect() in the ReadAsset and Unload functions, this seemed to be the only way to prevent crashing on devices with limited resources when attempting to "replace" current loaded data as in, for example, a theme change or moving from level to level with largely varying content. It also seems to be the only way to prevent a memory leak from occurring especially on Windows UAP because of the rather delayed collection intervals, the following graphs should clarify what I mean:

The current memory stats while I continuously switch between 2 sets of textures on UAP:

Without collect calls:
![nogc](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10683997/10112741/23813bc4-63de-11e5-9f5e-a464837085b6.PNG)

The memory simply grows endlessly in a memory leak resembling pattern. This memory is NOT reusable as this test would crash the 512mb emulator or a low end device immediately (Also reported on android by a project member). The memory is occasionally collected by the GC to a slightly lower value but this behavior would continue until the memory is out.

After adding collect calls:
![agc](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10683997/10112869/1abd2e48-63df-11e5-96f6-b77a3408920e.PNG)

The issue has been reduced to those spikes, which I have found to be associated with the async nature of the WINRT file system, but so far I have not thought of a solution to this probelm. Also calling GC.Collect() once after the loading process on game side does not reduce memory usage as opposed to the call once per ReadAsset.

Note: Visual studio reformatted the document (which I have found conforming to the guidelines) so here are the lines I edited to make it easier for anyone interested in seeing the actual change.
215                  Unload(asset)
248,377,687  GC.Collect()

data.title: Fix For XAudio Voice Leak
data.body:
This is a leak fix with a simple optimization for reuse of voices in XAudio.  It affected any game that relies on `SoundEffect.Play()` or XAct.  It seems like the OpenAL implementation suffers from a similar leak, but that is left to another PR.

Also there is missing optimization here that I added a `TODO` comment for.  We should be finding a `SoundEffectInstance` from the pool that is the format we need else return a new instance.  That is left for another PR.

It would be good for a few people to test this with their games before we merge this.

Thanks to @mrhelmut for the test project that exposed this issue.

Fixes #4146.

data.title: Win Pipeline Tool wrong platform selection
data.body:
So enmus WindowsGL and Linux point to enum DesktopGL, but the problem is that Windows PropertyGrid read the enum Linux first, and since it had the same value as the other 2 it decided to just give "Linux" 3 times in target platform selection instead of giving "WindowsGL", "Linux" and "Mac".

![untitled3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6773302/10102661/fee2f5de-639f-11e5-87a6-f05e934dacb3.png)

data.title: Fix for DesktopGL Exit errors
data.body:
Fixes: #3540

Stuff done:
- Fixes BadWindow, BadCursor and OpenTK: Failed to make context current errors
  - was occurring because of window getting Disposed before the rest of the things completed like disposing of Textures(which require a valid window handle) and was also because of Run Loop stopping with processing of events for the window which would close the window and also make that handle invalid.
- Fixes AL Sources Error
  - whoever wrote the code didn't dispose of the sources at the end... nothing major
- Fixes AL Device Not Closed error
  - was occurring because of the BadWindow and BadCursor errors were stopping dispose from completing
- Fixed native stacktrace error
  - was occurring because of _toolkit.Dispose()... it's an error within OpenTK, but since _toolkit was an unused variable I just removed it

data.title: Added support for MSBuild.Content.Builder on MacOS
data.body:
In order to support the Content.Builder.targets on
MacOS we firstly needed to install the Tooling and
Assemblies in the right location. In this case
/Library/Frameworks/MonoGame.framework/vX.X.X.X

Symbolic links are required to get everything working
right. In this case we need a v3.0 link in
/Library/Frameworks/MonoGame.framework but we also need
some links in the Mono.framework as well. Namely

/Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/External/MonoGame

We also need to add an Imports element to the csproj files.
Now the current MonoDevleop/Xamarin Studio templating system
does not support doing this directly. So a new MSBuild
processing class has been added to the addin. This class
will check if the project is a "MonoGame" project (is references
MonoGame.Framework.dll or has a MonoGamePlatform element) and
inject the required data into the csproj.

The templates have been left referencing the Nuget packages
for now.

Modified the ContentBuilder targets file to Batch its items
this is to get round issues when running under xbuild on Mac.

Updated templates to use a new MonoGameInstallDirectory property
rather than $(MSBuildProgramFiles32) so that we can use the
same paths for references.

It also adds the followiing to the projects

```
<MonoGameInstallDirectory Condition="'$(OS)' != 'Unix' ">$(MSBuildProgramFiles32)</MonoGameInstallDirectory>
<MonoGameInstallDirectory Condition="'$(OS)' == 'Unix' ">$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)</MonoGameInstallDirectory>
```

So that we can resolve the directory correctly on both Windows
Mac and Linux

data.title: Windows DirectX: Occasionally crashes when entering fullscreen mode
data.body:
A few of my testers keep reporting the following crash when launching my game:

```
Type: SharpDX.SharpDXException
Message: HRESULT: [0x887A0022], Module: [SharpDX.DXGI], ApiCode: [DXGI_ERROR_NOT_CURRENTLY_AVAILABLE/NotCurrentlyAvailable], Message: A resource is not available at the time of the call, but may become available later.

Source: SharpDX
Stack Trace:
   at SharpDX.Result.CheckError()
   at SharpDX.DXGI.SwapChain.SetFullscreenState(Bool fullscreen, Output targetRef)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.CreateSizeDependentResources(Boolean useFullscreenParameter)
   at MonoGame.Framework.WinFormsGamePlatform.EnterFullScreen()
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.DoInitialize()
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Run(GameRunBehavior runBehavior)
   at FinalDays.Client.Program.Main(String[] args)
```

The crash is intermittent, and usually it works fine if they try and launch the game a second time.

Looking at the exception details, it seems to be related to entering fullscreen mode when the game is starting up.

I've personally only experienced this crash once when using fullscreen mode before. But typically I am always running in windowed mode while testing, so that's probably why I've only seen it once.

I'm planning to take a closer look into this myself sometime soon hopefully, but I was hoping that maybe someone else might have seen this before and know what the cause is.

data.title: MonoGame Not Strongly-Named Assembly
data.body: I'm trying to use MonoGame inside my application (which must be signed), but I can't because MonoGame assembly (and the referenced SharpDX assemblies I've noticed) is not signed (is not a strongly-named assembly).  Is it possible to sign them (at least the NuGet version)?  I'd rather not have to go through the fuss of building my own version of everything just to sign them.

data.title: Couple issues with XAudio2 (corruption, freeze)
data.body:
Hey there,

We are getting a few reports related to sfx which may be dependent to a few sound chip manufacturers.
Here are the issues, which may be unrelated, but we highly suspect that they are:
1. **Sound corruption**: after playing for an extended time (~1 hour), `SoundEffect` / `SoundEffectInstance` get corrupted. All sounds start to crackle a lot. `MediaPlayer` / `Song` are not affected (which seems normal since `MediaPlayer` uses MediaFoundation and not XAudio2).
2. **Freezes / stalls**: when sounds start to crackle, it is almost certain that playing a non pooled `SoundEffectInstance` (i.e. through `SoundEffect.CreateInstance()`) will totally stall the game for several seconds. `SoundEffect.Play()` (i.e. pooled instances) doesn't stall the game.

I'm totally puzzled about these issues and we haven't been able to reproduce them internally which makes me think that they are related to specific sound chips and possibly driver issues.

It may also be only related to looped `SoundEffectInstance`, because they tend to make the game stall more often/quickly.

I also don't know why only non-pooled instances are making the game to stall. I would suspect an hardware instance limit, but since the pool doesn't have a limit on Windows platforms, the problem would have been exposed way before any non-pooled instance is played.

I haven't found the time to test that against OpenAL.

data.title: Windows 10 "There may have been a missing assembly."
data.body:
Hello Community,

I'm building a Windows 10 Universal game. When I create a release package for it, I always get the following warnings.

``` C#
Type 'Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Panel' was not included in compilation, but was referenced in type 'Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.InputDialog'. There may have been a missing assembly.  

Type 'Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Border' was not included in compilation, but was referenced in type 'Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.InputDialog'. There may have been a missing assembly. 

Type 'Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.TextBox' was not included in compilation, but was referenced in type 'Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.InputDialog'. There may have been a missing assembly.    

Type 'Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.TextBlock' was not included in compilation, but was referenced in type 'Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.InputDialog'. There may have been a missing assembly.

Type 'Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives.ButtonBase' was not included in compilation, but was referenced in type 'Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.InputDialog'. There may have been a missing assembly.  

Type 'Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.PasswordBox' was not included in compilation, but was referenced in type 'Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.InputDialog'. There may have been a missing assembly.
```

I'm using MS Live ID login that pops up a login screen and a permission request using the native interface of the platform that is crashing on a lot of devices (except mine). I believe that if I can fix these warnings, I might have a chance of fixing the crashing bug.

I'm using Monogame SDK 3.5.0.525.

I'm also very thankful to everybody that put amazing work on porting Monogame to Windows 10 earlier than all other frameworks/engines. :)

Thanks in advance.

data.title: SoundEffect instance has distortion after effect is played.
data.body:
When trying top play a sound on Windows with the SoundEffect instance, I get distortion and/or white noise after the effect has finished playing, for about the same duration as the sound effect.
In my particular case, I am loading a sound effect via the SoundEffect.FromStream method.

The following thread has more detail regarding the issue and a possible fix.

http://community.monogame.net/t/created-soundeffect-plays-corruption-at-end/1644/7

data.title: Added a null check on Window disposal
data.body: We are getting a few crash reports related to `WinFormsGamePlatform.Exit()` throwing NullException's. I haven't identified why it is called multiple times (most probably gamers button mashing the exit button), but this little null check shouldn't harm. :)

-BlendFactor added to GraphicsDevice and acts as an easy way to access to GraphicsDevice.BlendState.BlendFactor.

Here's a sample of the command I'm running:

I've tried rearranging the order of the commands listed. Nothing seems to work. 

Ps. I'm using the latest stable version (3.4)

data.title: Support for textures with mipmaps and cubemaps from DDS files
data.body:
General clean-up of texture processing for all faces and mipmaps contained in the imported texture.

Fixes #4062.

data.title: DesktopGL templates
data.body:
Stuff done:
- Removed WindowsGL templates and renamed Linux templates to MonoGame OpenGL
- Completely removed Linux assemblies from installer, they are literally the same as WindowsGL ones
- Made templates WinExe, this means they are graphical exe, was set to Exe which meant it was a console application

data.title: GraphicsMetrics update
data.body:
This is update for GraphicsMetrics which resolves https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4111

I also makes all metrics values appends after actual calls(for example DrawCount will appends after PlatformDrawPrimitives and not before) - which is more nice in my opinion, and changed docs a bit.

data.title: Make the Title Container resolve resources properly on WinRT
data.body:
When you call the TitleContainer.OpenStream method on Windows platforms,
it needs to lookup the location of the specified resource. This is
because on Windows 10, resources may be stored outside of the main
application folder when using an "application bundle" (now the default
setting).

data.title: MonoGameTests errors regarding 'd3dcompiler_47.dll'

I'm running Windows 7 x64 machine and tried to compile it in Visual Studio 2015 Comunnity Edition... I was following (most of the time...) guide found here https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/wiki/Tutorials:-Getting-Started-on-Windows-with-Visual-Studio
I was trying to build and run projects in solution MonoGame.Framework.Windows.sln

Any possible help? From my search so far, it seems to be somehow linked to Windows 8.1 SDK...

data.title: Mouse.GetState() always returns 0, 0?
